Colin, thanks for your comments.  I agree that there is room for a number=
 of interesting variants of the general idea of searching the hypercube for=
 meaningful connections (and hence their associated nodes).  Hopefully this=
 paper will help to open up research in that direction.

At the same time I=
 think our results do suggest the potential danger of coevolving connectivi=
ty and node placement, even though it seems intuitive.  Decoupling connecti=
ons from nodes may create a situation in the search something like a dog ch=
asing its own tail.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.g=
reen1@...> wrote:
>
> On 23 March 2010 21:39, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
> >=

> > After years of speculation on how the placement and density of nodes m=
ight be evolved in
> > the HyperNEAT substrate, Sebastian Risi, Joel Lehman=
, and I are pleased to announce
> > our contribution to this conversation. =
Our paper, "Evolving the Placement and Density of
> > Neurons in the HyperN=
EAT Substrate," which will be presented at GECCO this year
> 
> Nice work, =
I really like the approach. I agree with the discussion at
> the end regard=
ing quad/hyper-trees not necessarily being the last
> word, that was one of=
 my first thoughts. And that ties in to some
> extent with the issue about =
number of nodes being generated being more
> than was strictly required - p=
erhaps variant approaches could be more
> conservative in how many nodes th=
ey produce, although there are
> pruning params already that influence this=
. The image of the evolved
> ANN was interestingly asymetric as well I thou=
ght, it had a natural
> look to it.
> 
> Overall though I think the obvious=
 approach to evolving substrate is
> to co-evolve it independently, so it w=
as nice to (A) show an
> alternative which probably will spark a range of n=
ews ideas, and (B)
> demonstrate the independently co-evolved substrate mig=
ht actually be
> inferior to an ES-NEAT like approach.
> 
> It will be inte=
resting to see this approach develop and be applied to
> progressivley more=
 difficult tasks.
> 
> Colin
>
